conclusion: To compare the average velocities of Car A and Car B from time t=0 to t=t1, we need to analyze the velocity-time graphs provided in the image.
The average velocity for each car can be calculated using the formula: Average Velocity = Total Displacement / Total Time.
Since the displacement is the area under the velocity-time graph, we need to calculate the area under each graph from t=0 to t=t1.
Car A starts at velocity v2 and ends at velocity v1.
Car B starts at velocity v1 and ends at velocity v2.
The graph for Car A is a straight line decreasing from v2 to v1.
The graph for Car B is a straight line increasing from v1 to v2.
The area under the graph represents the displacement.
The graph for Car A forms a trapezoid with bases v2 and v1 and height t1.
Area (Displacement) for Car A = 1/2 * (v2 + v1) * t1.
The graph for Car B forms a trapezoid with bases v1 and v2 and height t1.
Area (Displacement) for Car B = 1/2 * (v1 + v2) * t1.
Since the areas (displacements) for both cars are equal, the average velocity for both cars will be the same.
Average Velocity for Car A = (v2 + v1) / 2.
Average Velocity for Car B = (v1 + v2) / 2.
Both cars have the same average velocity over the time interval from t=0 to t=t1.
The average velocities of Car A and Car B are equal over the time interval from t=0 to t=t1.
